Rowling Draco Malfoy/Harry Potter Draco Malfoy, Harry Potter, Ron Weasley, Hermione Granger Accidental Bonding, Bedsharing, Forced Proximity, Bickering, Banter, Community: hd_erised, maybe slight dub-con for drunken snogging, Consensual Canoodling, Auror Training, bookshops, Bars and Pubs, Harry's Canonical Chest Monster, Semi-Public Frotting, First Kisses, Domesticity, Unexpected Nicolas Cage English 2016-12-27 Completed 2016-12-27 18,752 1/1 331 9,881 1,803 122,299 ['DanceOnKnives', 'falling_dominos', 'Rossmery_12', 'readforheath', 'miyato', 'Moniebear', 'teteseokiee', 'OhMyFreddy', 'Min_Anniee', 'Daisy_James17', 'underwaterattribute', 'marymacdonaldkisser', '01kings', 'MaskedmRose', 'coolbeans99', 'Himeka11', 'Erdbeere6', 'neilreads', 'gudetamayo', 'aspiringPhysicist', 'Basil_Beee', 'eluirii', 'Razzleberry_Jam', 'raventosnake', 'Lanatic707', 'Thesecretconstant', 'computergrll', 'rutilaecomae', 'Ase_the_idiot', 'outOftheworld', 'Tommy_0', 'kohhigh95', 'saruabreo', 'Monocleless', 'lili_la', 'freyafreya', 'PlantHarry', 'swarls', 'ifonlylove', 'Raffysbrazzi', 'yoonspeanut', 'Gac24663', 'Varecia', 'Xedra', 'humblebumblebooks', 'comet_tails', 'citylightlukey', 'siegeofangels', 'ChAnGe4theBetTer', 'Winchesters114'] [] Harry had been certain that things would go poorly from the very instant he found out that Draco Malfoy would be his partner for the next six weeks, because when had anything involving him and Malfoy ever gone well?

But even knowing that from the very beginning, when he later looked back on all of this, he would still find himself surprised--and vaguely impressed--that he and Malfoy had somehow managed to make a total cock-up of it within the first twenty minutes.

It was even more impressive when he took into consideration that their assignment wasn't supposed to be at all dangerous. By now, six months into their training, The Magical Law Enforcement Patrol had begun shunting over some of their least perilous assignments so that the Auror trainees could go out and get a little bit of practical experience to go along with the endless heaps of coursework they were assigned. Harry had been looking forward to this for months, and he and Ron exchanged eager grins at the thought of finally getting out of the classroom and into the field.

But Harry's excitement rapidly collapsed into limp resignation when the instructor announced that instead of being allowed to choose their own partners, as they'd been previously allowed to do for classwork and training assignments, they were to be put in pairs alphabetically. Ron gave Harry a pitying look at that, because their class of trainees was fairly small, and that meant that no one came between Malfoy and Potter. And while they'd all mostly put their differences aside and did their best to put the past behind them, they still didn't particularly like each other. It was only the smallest consolation that Malfoy didn't look any more pleased about their assignment than Harry felt.

And so now here was Harry, trapped with Malfoy in a cramped evidence room, sorting through a trunk full of magical miscellanea that had somehow ended up in a Muggle charity shop. Two more trunks sat stacked in the corner, and Harry's afternoon stretched interminably before him. Sighing, he set aside the hand mirror he held, and dutifully marked it down on the inventory sheet.

"This is all junk," Malfoy complained, pulling out a handful of photographs. The people in them--at a wedding, judging from the young witch's elaborate white robes--waved and smiled. Malfoy tossed them carelessly into a nearby evidence box, then reached for his quill and added the photographs to the list of inventory.

"Yeah, but it's obviously wizarding junk," Harry told him evenly. It helped a little that Malfoy had so far only complained about the job and not about Harry himself, but the constant griping was still beginning to wear on Harry's patience.

He pulled out a small brass music box that, when opened, played a tinkling rendition of 'You Charmed the Heart Right Out of Me.' That might make a good Christmas gift for Molly, Harry thought as he shut the music box and put it in with the other things they'd already looked through. She loved Celestina Warbeck. He'd have to see if he could find one of those that wasn't evidence in an active investigation.

"So what?" Malfoy said sulkily, sifting through the trunk and coming up with a huge floppy-brimmed hat trimmed with blue silk ribbon rosettes and taxidermied puffskeins. He held it out consideringly, and for one wild moment, Harry thought he was about to try it on. "It's not as if Muggles will be able to tell the difference."

"Malfoy," Harry sighed. "You are holding a hat decorated with actual magical creatures. Right in your hands. I'm sure that Muggles would be able to figure out that puffskeins are a sort of animal they've never seen before. They'd be falling all over themselves to discover a new species, and the absolute last thing we need is an uproar in the scientific community."

"There would be no such thing," Malfoy said as he crammed the hat into the box with the photographs, shoving down hard to make it fit. He folded the box flaps down and sealed them with a spell. "They're all willfully ignorant. Muggles don't believe in anything that doesn't fit with their astoundingly narrow little world view."

"Know that many Muggles, do you?" Harry asked, resisting the urge to roll his eyes. He handed over the inventory sheet and Malfoy slapped it on top, affixed it with a Sticking Charm, and covered it with another charm to protect it.

"I don't need to know them," Malfoy said loftily. A swish of his wand sent the evidence box to the far corner with the rest of the boxes they'd filled so far. "Everybody knows how Muggles are."

Harry bit his tongue as he looked into the bottom of the trunk while Malfoy got a new evidence box and a blank inventory sheet. Continuing this ridiculous argument wouldn't do either of them any favors, and the afternoon would go faster if they kept working and didn't allow themselves to become distracted by bickering with each other.

They were nearly halfway through this trunk, and that hadn't taken long at all. There were two more trunks so they could be done in about another hour. Then all they had to do was take the boxes and empty trunks down to Evidence, submit their inventory lists to the Patrolmen who were investigating where these magical items had come from, and then they'd be done. Harry could put up with Malfoy for that much longer. They'd be finished before he knew it.

Willfully ignoring that tomorrow he'd have to come back and face another full day of Malfoy, Harry bit back a sigh and took out a silver compact with a cabbage rose etched into the top. He just had to get through this afternoon. Small goals. Reasonable goals. He could do this.

"You look lovely, dear!" trilled the little round mirror inside when Harry flipped the lid open, and Malfoy snorted.

"Well that's obviously defective," he said. "Make sure you note that in the inventory, will you? Enchanted mirror can't tell the difference between an attractive person and a speccy git. Maybe you ought to give it your glasses."

And, wonderful. They'd now moved on to personal insults.

Harry resisted the urge to throw the compact right at Malfoy's head. Instead, he snapped it shut and dropped it in the evidence box. He very deliberately ignored Malfoy and reached down into the trunk for a length of braided silk cord that he saw sticking out of the rest of the junk, preparing to pull it loose, and didn't realize that Malfoy had grabbed the other end of it until a sudden crackle of magic flared to life between them, and the cords glowed gold and wrapped themselves around Harry's and Malfoy's wrists.

Harry jerked back in surprised, wrenching his arm free. The glow faded and the cords slipped from around Malfoy's wrist and fell limply to the ground.

"What the fuck was that?" Harry asked, looking from the cords to Malfoy's face, and his heart sank like a pebble tossed into a pool. If the stricken expression on Malfoy's face was anything to go by, then whatever had just happened was very bad indeed. "Malfoy?" he asked, rubbing idly at his wrist where a lingering trace of magic made his skin tingle. "What just happened?"

"It would appear that those are handfasting cords," Malfoy said shakily, pushing up his sleeve. And there, around his right wrist, was a dark brown mark like a coiled rope. "And we've just bonded ourselves to each other."

Alarmed, Harry pushed up his own sleeve and found the same mark on his own wrist. He rubbed at it. "We're bonded?" he blurted out, panic rising.

Malfoy cast a slew of spells at himself and Harry, and whatever he saw in the results made him sag in relief. "Temporarily," he said. "It's only temporary. It appears to be a type of spell that's sometimes used in political marriages, or to marriages arranged to solidify relations between two families. It encourages the newlyweds to spend time together. You know, really make a go of it. Typically, the spell will only last about a month."

Make a go of it? What did that even mean? And a month? Harry had to make a go of it with Malfoy for a whole month?

Malfoy heaved a theatrically large sigh. "You needn't look so alarmed. This is inconvenient, but hardly an emergency."

"Well sorry," Harry told him. He took a deep breath and tried to will his heart to stop thumping. Malfoy wouldn't be this calm if there was really something to be alarmed over. Whatever the spells he'd cast had told him, it'd been enough to make him relax about it. "It's not like they teach this stuff in school."

Malfoy leveled a scathing look at him. "You're an Auror trainee, aren't you?"

"Yeah, well, they haven't taught this stuff here, either," Harry told him. "Look, instead of going on about how this is something I should already know, why don't you save us both a lot of bother and just tell me?"

"Bonds are like any other magic," Malfoy said, folding his arms over his chest and looking down his nose at Harry. "The stronger the effect of the spell, the more intent they require to cast. This," He gestured at the handfasting cords, "didn't require any intent from us. Therefore, it's not a powerful spell."

He had this I honestly can't believe I've actually got to explain this to you sort of tone to his voice that made Harry want to punch him right in his pointy nose.

But alas, punching Malfoy (as satisfying as it'd undoubtedly be) would probably only make him even more inclined to be an arsehole about this.

"So it can be undone?" Harry asked instead.

"Of course it can," Malfoy said, and he still had that infuriatingly superior tone to his voice. "If we went to St Mungo's, they could have it undone in about five seconds."

A great wash of relief swept through Harry. "Fantastic. Let's go." It's not as if sorting through this junk couldn't wait an hour or so while he and Malfoy got themselves seen to.

"No," Malfoy said, bringing Harry up short. "We're not going."

"What? Why?" Harry asked, baffled. "You just said they could undo the bond."

"Yes, they can. And if we go, there'll be a record of it."

Harry gaped at him. "Wait, really? You'd rather spend a month stuck together than report this?"

"As loathe as I am to admit that we fucked up this badly on our very first assignment, no, that's not what I meant," Malfoy said. "I want you to think very carefully, Potter. This happened in a matter of seconds. Going to St Mungo's would involve people finding out what happened. I wouldn't be surprised if it'd make the papers, seeing as how the entire bloody world is endlessly fascinated with everything you do. Do you really want this to get out into the world where some of your, how shall we say, your more dedicated fans might hear of it and get ideas?"

Harry's stomach clenched. He thought of Romilda Vane. All it'd take was one gossipy Mediwitch or Mediwizard, one patient overhearing something they shouldn't, just one person going to the papers. Even four weeks of Malfoy's unrelenting company would be better than the sheer ongoing hell that would come of this if the papers ran a story about what had happened, because at least there'd be an end to Malfoy. At least Harry knew that Malfoy wouldn't do anything worse to him than pick a fight or two or twelve, and Harry had plenty of experience with Malfoy acting like a complete arsehole.

But why should Malfoy care? He wouldn't be affected by any of that, if the story got out. And there was no way he was offering to protect Harry out of the goodness of his heart. He'd want something for it. And Harry was willing to bet he already had something in mind.

"Why would you do this for me? What do you want in return?" he asked.

"I owe you a Life Debt," Malfoy said right away. "I want to be absolved of that."

Harry had never intended to call it in--the idea of forcing anyone to do his will made him deeply uncomfortable--so it was a small enough price to pay. "Deal," he said, offering his hand.

After a brief hesitation, Malfoy reached out and they shook. His fingers were cold and a little clammy, and Harry rubbed his hand on his thigh after they let go.

"Now what?" Harry asked.

"Now we do our jobs and finish with these bloody trunks," Malfoy said. He picked up one of the paper envelopes layered with protective charms they'd been given for anything that might pose a threat. He enlarged it with a tap of his wand, picked up the handfasting cords and slipped them inside, sealed it, labeled it, and tossed it in the evidence box. Then he lifted a silver cigarette case out of the trunk.

"So, you mentioned effects," Harry said after a few minutes. "What exactly are we facing?"

Malfoy gave him a put-upon look as he tossed the cigarette case into the evidence box and made an entry for it on the inventory list. Harry clenched his teeth and waited him out.

"We're required to spend time together," Malfoy said. He picked up a fancy crystal inkwell, and held it up to the light to examine a smudge of dried blue ink in the bottom.

"And that's all?" Harry prompted when Malfoy didn't seem inclined to continue. "How much time do we have to spend together?"

"Enough to satisfy the bond," Malfoy said. "We'll have to test it later to see how long we can be apart."

"What happens then?" Harry asked, patience rapidly wearing thin. Getting answers out of Malfoy was like pulling teeth.

"A wide variety of highly unpleasant physical effects," Malfoy said. "Weakness, fatigue, insomnia, nausea, headache, et cetera, et cetera. The effects get worse the longer the bonded couple spends away from each other."

All of that sounded horrible. "Okay, so we spend time together. That won't be so hard. I mean, we're going to be working together for the next six weeks."

"We'll have to live together, too," Malfoy said. "Sharing a bed is one of the typical requirements of bonds like these."

Harry froze. "Sharing a bed?" he echoed.

"It's a bond typically used for marriages, Potter," Malfoy snapped. "Trust me, I'm not thrilled about this, either."

It took some effort, but Harry bit back a retort. He bit back a great load of swearing, too. He took a deep breath, then another, and another, until the urge to hex Malfoy subsided. "So, spending lots of time together, living together, sharing a bed. Is there anything else this bond is going to make us do?"

"What, that's not enough for you?" Malfoy drawled, and the last thread of Harry's patience gave way.

"I don't know why you're forcing me to drag each piece of information out of you, but this is going to be enough of a challenge to get through without you deliberately being an obnoxious dickhead," Harry told him.

Malfoy opened his mouth, then shut his mouth again, then very quietly said, "All right." And it wasn't anything even approaching an apology, but Harry had a feeling it was probably the best he could expect.

"All right, then," Harry echoed, sitting back in his seat.

"There's not much more to it than I've already said," Malfoy told Harry after a moment. He picked up a pewter figurine of a rearing unicorn from the trunk and examined it. "Sharing a bed, keeping close by each other. Sometimes talking can be a requirement, but we shouldn't have any trouble with that one, as we'll have to talk for work, at least." He took a breath. "And touch." His gaze darted up to Harry and then away again quick as a blink. "They usually require touch."

"Wait," Harry said as an image of himself getting fucked by Malfoy flashed through his mind. "We don't have to have sex, do we?"

Malfoy's cheeks were turning steadily pinker. "Most likely not," he said, which wasn't the solid No that Harry had hoped for, but was certainly better than a definite Yes. "The point of this sort of bond is to encourage two people to get to know each other in the hopes that they'll eventually grow to love each other on their own. Forcing them into doing something they're not ready for rather defeats the point."

"But forcing them to share a bed doesn't do that," Harry said skeptically.

"That's a different sort of intimacy," Malfoy said, still not looking at Harry. "Sex complicates things in a way that sharing a bed won't."

And Harry supposed he really couldn't argue with that. Sighing a little to himself, he returned his attention to the job at hand. He reached into the trunk and pulled out a little ceramic bell, and picked up his quill to record it on his inventory.

- - -x- - -

Everything went well enough until it was time to leave. Touch, as it turned out, was in fact a requirement of the bond. Thirty minutes after accidentally triggering the spell, a faint itching started up under Harry's skin, and Malfoy sighed and said, "Bollocks."

Fortunately, the bond didn't seem to require skin contact, and was easily satisfied by Malfoy stretching out his leg and resting the toe of his polished leather shoe against the side of Harry's trainer for a few minutes. By the third time Malfoy's foot nudged up against his, Harry barely even noticed. They finished sorting through the trunks, delivered the evidence boxes and trunks to Evidence and submitted their paperwork, and they were free to go for the day.

But go where was currently the topic of some debate.

"You live in the old Black place, don't you?" Malfoy asked, looking down his nose. "Absolutely not. We'll be staying in my flat."

"There's more space at mine," Harry tried to argue. "It's a whole house."

"Yes, but we're going to have to stay close to each other," Malfoy countered. "Having space isn't exactly an issue we need to resolve."

"Mine's got a house-elf," Harry said. He wasn't sure that Kreacher was truly a selling point, but he was banking on the fact that Malfoy had never actually met him.

"Mine doesn't have mice," Malfoy said.

"My house doesn't have mice," Harry said defensively. Well, it didn't have many mice. But it was an old house that had been inhabited only occasionally over the last two decades, and Auror training kept Harry busy. He had noticed the occasional scratching sound coming from the walls, and he did keep meaning to do something about it, but he just hadn't got around to it yet. Besides, winter was setting in and that's when Grimmauld Place's annual Doxy infestation tended to flare up, and god only knew why they liked that bloody house so much but each year they swarmed in by the dozens. Really it made sense to wait and then take care of all of it at once, as he'd vaguely been planning to do. And now that Harry thought about it, maybe having Malfoy living with him wouldn't be the best idea after all. "It doesn't," he insisted anyhow.

Malfoy only arched his eyebrows skeptically. "Generations of Blacks have lived in that house and were unable to get rid of the mice. It's practically family legend at this point. Yet you expect me to believe that you were somehow able to manage? In, what, seven months?"

"I'm the Chosen One?" Harry tried. Malfoy gave him a flat look, and Harry sighed, defeated. "Fine. We'll stay at your flat."

"Lovely," Malfoy said. "So glad we've got that sorted."

Malfoy gave Harry his Floo address, and then Harry went to Grimmauld Place to pack up his things. He stamped soot from his shoes, then started up the stairs, unbuttoning the heavy robes of his Auror uniform as he went.

He'd taken the second largest bedroom in the house, partly because the master bedroom still smelled faintly of hippogriff, no matter what Harry tried to do to remove the smell, and partly because sleeping in the cavernous master bedroom would have only served as even more of a reminder that he was rattling around this big old place all by himself. So he took the smaller bedroom and he tried not to think about the rest of it as best he could. And in any case, this bedroom was on the same floor as the sitting room, which meant that he had to climb up and down less flights of stairs, so using it really did make the most sense.

After he changed into a pair of jeans and a warm jumper, he tromped up to the attic to fetch his old school trunk. Back down in the bedroom, he packed it with his uniform robes, jeans and shirts and jumpers, pants and socks, and a wool peacoat. A flick of his wand toward the bathroom brought a collection of bottles and jars zipping through the air to deposit themselves into the trunk, soap and shampoo and shaving cream and toothpaste, a toothbrush and a razor, and a fluffy white bath towel. He piled in all his textbooks and class notes, quills and ink and parchment, then threw the backlog of Quidditch magazines that'd been steadily accumulating over the last six months on top. Auror training kept him so busy that he didn't think he'd need anything else while he was staying at Malfoy's. And even if he did forget something, he could stop by easily enough to get it later.

After a quick trip down to the kitchen to inform Kreacher that he'd be away (Kreacher had been, as Harry had expected, entirely indifferent) and pick up his favorite mug and a box of the tea he preferred, Harry was ready to leave. He hauled his trunk over to the Floo and hesitated. Traveling with a large object wasn't against the law, per se, but the Floo Network Authority did tend to frown upon it. Baggage-related incidents were the second most common cause of Floo Network injuries, and the whole point of staying bonded to Malfoy was to avoid St Mungo's.

But fuck it, Harry thought to himself as he scooped up a good handful of Floo powder from the repurposed jam jar on the mantel. He was willing to gamble that getting himself accidentally bonded to Malfoy was the worst thing that would happen to him today.

He was pleased when that turned out to be true. Harry stumbled from Malfoy's Floo and managed to get himself out of the way just in time for his trunk to come clattering out behind him, bringing with it a spray of soot.

Harry supposed he'd feel worse about it if he weren't so busy feeling impressed with himself that he'd taken his trunk through the Floo and hadn't earned himself a trip to the hospital. He breathed out a soft sigh of relief and looked around at the place he'd be living in for the next four weeks.

Malfoy's flat was not at all what Harry had imagined. He'd expected something like the Manor, cold and formal, all pale marble and high ceilings, and filled with the sort of furniture that people bought more for decoration than comfort. But Malfoy's flat was warm and surprisingly cozy, with dark wood floors and huge windows. Malfoy had about four bookcases worth of books crammed onto two bookcases, and his sofa and the two matching chairs that flanked it had thick cushions that looked wonderfully soft and inviting. A large Persian rug completed the room, and thank god the soot hadn't quite made it that far.

Malfoy came in as Harry was still casting charms to clean the floor. "Good Merlin," he sighed, sounding enormously put-upon. "Is this what I can expect from you?"

"Well," Harry said with very-obviously forced cheerfulness, casting another Scourgify. "Start as you mean to go on."

"Brilliant," Malfoy said, then sighed again. "Bedroom's through there, I cleared out the left half of the wardrobe and the bottom two bureau drawers for your things."

"Oh," Harry said, caught momentarily flat-footed by Malfoy's unexpected generosity. He'd been prepared to live out of his trunk for the next month. "Thanks. That's very thoughtful of you."

"Hardly," Malfoy said. "I just didn't think I'd be able to stand looking at you in wrinkled robes. Come into the kitchen when you're done. I've got dinner on."

"Thanks," Harry said to Malfoy's retreating back. He grabbed his trunk and lugged it into the bedroom.

Malfoy had painted his walls a soothing shade of blue and decorated them with what looked like illustrated pages from his old Hogwarts Astronomy textbook enlarged and framed. A plush navy blue area rug covered most of the floor, with a soft, thick pile that just begged Harry to dig his toes into it. The furniture was all plain, dark wood, and there was a heavy ceramic lamp in the shape of a Romanian Longhorn on the nightstand, with jewel eyes and an upturned snout and the white lampshade bent into a whimsical shape that looked like a puff of smoke being exhaled.

And then there was the bed.

Objectively, it was a very nice bed; it looked soft and inviting, with a puffy duvet in a crisp white cover and a whole heap of fluffy pillows piled up against the headboard. But to Harry, knowing that in a few short hours he'd be climbing into it with Malfoy, together, the mere sight of it made his nerves tie themselves up in knots.

Harry did his best to put it from his mind, and quickly put his things away, hanging his robes in the wardrobe and putting stacks of tee-shirts and trousers and socks and pants neatly into the bureau drawers Malfoy had cleared for him. When he finished, he closed his trunk and put it against the wall under the window. He didn't see any reason to unpack the rest of it right now.

Then, bracing himself, he turned and went to join Malfoy in the kitchen.

- - -x- - -

Later that evening, Harry lingered in the bathroom as long as he could reasonably get away with, dawdling as he washed his face and brushed his teeth and changed into his pajamas.

Then, when he could put it off no longer, he shut off the light, stood there in the darkness for a moment to gather his nerve, and then opened up the door.

Malfoy was already in bed when Harry stepped back into the bedroom, curled up on the right side and facing the wall, leaving the left side of the bed empty for Harry. He stared at Malfoy--the shape his his shoulder made under the covers and the way his hair looked almost gold against the crisp white of the pillowcase--and forced down a fresh wave of panic. He'd been nervous enough about this when the bed was empty; facing the bed with Malfoy in it, with the corner of the sheets on Harry's side turned invitingly down, ready and waiting for him to get in, well. Harry wasn't at all prepared for this.

He swallowed hard and told himself he was being ridiculous. There wasn't anything worse than a bit of awkwardness that could possibly come of this. This would be fine. There was nothing at all to be worried about.

Harry got into bed, leaned over to turn off the lamp, slid his glasses safely under his pillow, then settled stiffly on his back.

"Turn over," Malfoy said without moving. "We can put our backs to each other. That ought to suffice for contact."

Harry thought about asking Malfoy to swap sides with him--he normally slept on his right side and lying with his back to Malfoy would put him on his left--but in the end he didn't say anything, just turned obediently over and scooted back, and his arse bumped against Malfoy's. Malfoy quickly shifted away, resettling himself so that their backs pressed together and there was space between the rest of them. Harry wanted to pull the pillow over his head and smother himself with it, because his arse had just touched Malfoy's arse. Touching of arses had just occurred, and worse, Harry's stupid brain refused to stop replaying how it had felt warm and surprisingly soft against his own, and now he was thinking about touching Malfoy's arse with his hands and oh god that was worse.

"Nngggh," Harry said and clasped a hand over his face as a wave of cringey shame washed over him.

Malfoy shifted around again, the warmth of his back against Harry's disappearing for a moment before he settled against him again. "Are you quite all right over there?"

"Fine," Harry said, and was pleased by how totally and completely normal his voice sounded. "I'm fine."

It had only been surprise, he decided. Because Malfoy's arse was warm and soft while the rest of him was sharp and bony and cold. That's all it was. Harry was just caught off guard by how touchable Malfoy's arse felt.

Wait. No. That wasn't--

Except oh god it was.

"Nngggh," Harry said again, this time with feeling.

"Potter," Malfoy said sharply.

"Sorry," Harry muttered, squeezing his eyes shut.

He thought he would have a hard time falling asleep, between lying on his left and lying next to Malfoy and the whole arse thing, but barely ten minutes later, he was out.

- - -x- - -

On the first morning of their forced cohabitation, Harry awoke to an empty bed. Yawning, he sat up and looked around, and found the bedroom quiet and dim. He hadn't even considered how bloody awkward it would feel to wake up next to Malfoy, but it looked like he would get to put off that particular experience until tomorrow.

He pushed himself out of bed and stretched, then pulled the covers neatly over the bed before he shuffled blearily out into the kitchen in search of his morning cuppa. He found Malfoy seated at the table with both hands curled loosely around a steaming mug, still wearing his green and white plaid pajama bottoms and a soft grey shirt. He had his long legs stretched out under the table, his bare feet looking very pale against the white tile floor, and the sunlight slanting in through the high window backlit his sleep-tousled hair bright gold.

Oh fuck, thought Harry when his heart gave a funny little shiver at the sight of Malfoy looking so soft and gentle and unexpectedly approachable. This is going to be a problem.

Malfoy startled a little when he finally noticed Harry, tugging the sleeves of his shirt farther down over his wrists.

"Morning," Malfoy said, his voice still mellow with sleep, and the sound of it sparked a little flutter in the pit of Harry's stomach. The bright wash of sunshine made his eyes look very clear and strangely colorless. "I thought you'd sleep for a while yet."

"Oh," Harry said, looking quickly away. "Well. Here I am."

"There's still hot water in the kettle," Malfoy said after a moment.

"Oh," said Harry. "That's, erm. Thanks. Thank you."

Malfoy was looking at him oddly, and Harry gave him a weak smile before he escaped to the other side of the kitchen. Malfoy had taken Harry's mug and set it beside the kettle for him, and that unexpected bit of thoughtfulness made the flutter in Harry's stomach grow more intense.

Because Malfoy was an attractive person, Harry couldn't deny that. He'd known for years that Malfoy was exactly his type. But for years that knowledge had only remained an idle observation because Malfoy was horrible and it was really hard to be properly attracted to someone when you also wanted to punch them in their stupid pointy nose all the time. But this Malfoy? Who was still a little sleepy and still a little rumpled, warm and loose and relaxed and for once not being a total arse?

Yeah. Harry could already see this was going to be a problem.

He took his time making his tea, lingering over it until the fluttering in his stomach slowly faded.

"Do you have anything you need to do today?" Harry asked as he took his mug over to the table. He hoped some conversation would distract him from himself, or that Malfoy would say something to remind Harry just how much he disliked Malfoy.

"You mean besides go into the Ministry?" Malfoy asked dryly. He stretched out his feet under the table as soon as Harry sat down so that they were touching. His toes were cold even through the warm layer of Harry's socks. "This morning's thrilling lecture topic is Application Requests for the Submission of Evidence Confirming Uncorroborated New Testimony. And why they think we need to know that, I haven't the faintest. Aurors have nothing to do with trying criminals. That's all the Wizengamot."

"I guess they want us to know all the aspects of how a case proceeds?" Harry offered even though he also thought it was ridiculous. Harry shifted his foot so it sat partially atop Malfoy's, covering up his cold toes. His heartbeat quickened and he did his best to ignore it. This was just Malfoy's foot; no reason to get worked up over that.

"Bloody waste of time," Malfoy muttered into his mug.

"So, if all you've got planned today is training, would you mind going out this evening?" Harry asked, opting to move the conversation along.

"We've got lecture again tomorrow morning," Malfoy said, frowning.

"I know, I know," Harry said. "It'd just be for a little while, we wouldn't be out late. It's just that I had plans to meet Ron and Hermione at a pub. Hermione's so busy with her job with the Department for the Regulation and Control of Magical Creatures that I hardly get to see her anymore. I mean, even Ron hardly gets to see her and they live together."

Malfoy grimaced. "Fine," he said. His foot twitched beneath Harry's. "But you're paying for my drinks."

"Deal," Harry said quickly.

Malfoy looked at him suspiciously. Had Harry said that too quickly? He'd probably said that too quickly. But Malfoy shook his head and went back to his tea, and Harry let it go.

He'd figure out how to convince Malfoy to go to a pub in Muggle London later. Harry had the whole day to wo

511 9,716 2,736 109,781 ['MiraiEstell', 'ADHDGremlin', 'oyaoyab1tch', 'Lunodragon', 'alexa5331', 'Estre11a', 'Panzer_vor', 'Vr101', 'Free_Fallen', 'ferixidades', 'Carnatiprajiti', 'MuiminaEchan', 'Randomapetheticreaderwriter789AR', 'Purple_fairy', 'oikawasbee', 'panuramine', 'alwaysandforeverhome', 'EverGreenDragon', 'Honeybeeicarus', 'nebulouss', 'mossy_garden_bitch', 'Manticor', 'trip', 'Todwk1', 'bluesdaisies', 'M17ch3111', 'CaleWorshipper', 'One_in_a_million_lives', 'Haze_of_Chaos', 'Beebbie', 'Ousire', 'Elliezgirl', 'XxToga_HimikoxX', '4_r4V3N_4ND_C4T', 'Thymelizabeth', 'HobieBrownsWhore', 'manamite', 'ManifestingLuck', '1_4m_Bra1n_r0t', 'ChrryPckd', 'ShiroAkuma14', 'HowlingStorm0', 'golden_fleecy', 'thelesgurluwu', 'annagri', 'Empress_of_Hellish_Desire_and_Sins', 'periodbloodandviscera', 'Shiropotreb', 'CupidsVultures', 'Emerald_Joker'] [] It's a quiet afternoon the day Midoriya Izuku learns he's quirkless.

He is a boy of dreams and passion, of wide eyes and determined smiles. He sees heroes on those bright screens and thinks, "I want to be like them." He sees the gratefulness and the admiration of those saved and rescued and thinks, "I want to save people like them." He sees them standing strong and tall, against terror and battles, and thinks "I want to be a hero like them."

It's a want, a deep-seated ambition, that is carved and etched into his muscles and bones, the way ink tattoos dyes skin an intricate black. He is four, but he thinks he's meant for more.

But the thing is, in a world such as his, society is built on power. It's a rule of the world, a fact, something that will never change no matter how much time passes. History is built on wars and blood, and no matter how the people of today sweeten it with light sugary words and white lies, it is a fact that the world is not built on understanding.

It is built on quirks, of strength blessed upon the lucky. It's a kind of strength that is god given, because there is no other way to explain now how men can call forth flames and nature onto their palms so naturally. And what are heroes, but people with a drive for fame and glory, wealth and riches, and overwhelming power at their fingertips?

It is a quiet afternoon when Midoriya Izuku's mother brings him to a man dressed in white, whose lips are pressed flatly together as he tells a child who holds dreams too big for him to hold, a boy who has nothing except a deep-seated selfish want for something more, that his dreams would amount to nothing but that. Distant dreams.

It is a quiet afternoon Midoriya Izuku is told he is quirkless, and as his mother holds him in his arms like he's cracked glass, as if he'd shatter the moment she presses too much, he thinks the world is cruel.

For whatever gods or beings who have given men wings to fly to a fate they want themselves and have tied boulders to his, he decides, world be damned, he'll tear them off and make his own wings to soar. He swears it.

And people reflect the world they live in, so they are mean and horrible, their words sharp and jagged. They cut into his flesh like poison-laced knives, and they are words that are engraved into his mind for years and years to come.

But a hero- well, heroes are strong, aren't they? Heroes wouldn't let words get to them. Heroes would hold tight to what they believe. Heroes are strong and big and powerful.

Heroes are-

"Useless Deku," Bakugou sneers, lips twisted into a derisive snarl. There's an anger in him that bubbles forth like magma, a hate that wasn't there before. "You'll never be a hero! You're a quirkless waste of space, and you should learn your place."

Heroes are good people, aren't they?

"Kacchan," Izuku tries weakly, bruises stinging on his arms and legs. They hurt and ache, they scream at him to still and stop and rest. He stumbles up instead. "Kacchan, you don't-"

Suddenly he's on the ground ( again ) and it burns. His ears ring loudly, his head muddled and foggy and he can't think straight, and then, "Shut up! Don't call me that!" Izuku blinks out the rising tears in his eyes as he tilts his head up, and sees Bakugou standing strong above him, looking down at him. Something bitter and hot scratches at his throat, and he bites his lips hard enough to draw blood.

"I'll be a hero," Bakugou says, an unrivalled confidence oozing out of his form, "and you'll just be Deku. A useless nobody."

And there are two truths in Izuku's life. Heroes are good. Kacchan doesn't lie.

So as he feels red heat drip down his chin, splattering on the dirt below him, feels the scratches and burns that throb on his shoulder and bare flesh, he wonders if this is what it means to be a hero. He wonders, for a long long time, if this is what good is.

Kacchan is going to be a hero. Heroes are good. He repeats this to himself every time he earns a new bruise, a new scar, a new burn, another concerned and worried look from his mother. And what is he?

Deku, he whispers aloud, at the dead of night in his room. Izuku Midoriya and Deku are one in the same, and to him, there is no telling where Deku ends and he begins. He starts to believe his new namesake.

So days drag on too long, rueful and scathing glances fixed on his small body becoming a common occurrence. He's used to it now. He has to be. He needs to be. Heroes are strong. Home is his only safe place, and so one day as he rushes there because it hurts going anywhere but there, he's met with the sight of his mother sobbing on the couch, tears staining her cheeks.

Heroes are strong.

"Mama?" he asks, keeping his voice steady. He quietly walks over to her shaking body, watching her curled form stiffen and turn to him, red-rimmed eyes meeting with wide green ones. A broken sob escapes her lips as she pulls him into a tight hug.

"Oh, Izuku, baby," she says wetly, trying but failing to keep her voice from cracking. "Your father- your father isn't coming back home."

It doesn't quite register completely, her words, as his little hand curls around his mother's wrinkled shirt. He feels his shoulder dampen, but he doesn't mind. Doesn't mind the jolt of pain that comes again when she holds him tight. He is strong. He'll be strong for his mother. He's smart enough to know at the news of this, there is nobody by their corner to help them except each other. There is no way to make ends meet.

"Mama," he says, as firmly as he can, "I'll find a job! I'll- I'll make all the money in the world! Then you won't need to worry!"

She smiles tearfully, brushing gently through his tangle of hair. "Sweetie, it'll be okay. I'll find a job and we'll- we'll be okay. You're going to be a hero, aren't you?"

Oh he does want to, so, so badly, and the thought of not becoming a hero has never crossed his mind. But he looks at his mother, fighting to hold a strong smile on her face, he thinks, for her, he'll throw away this dream of his. Heroes save people, don't they? It'll be fine, for him, if he only saves one person. And it's even better if it's his Mama. Anything, if it's his Mama. He beams back at her, bright and wide.

"It's fine Mama," he says. And with a strange brutal honesty, "I'm quirkless. I-" he gulps, "I can't become a hero. But I'll save you!"

Inko says nothing and only pulls him closer, whispering reassurances for the both of them. Izuku buries the little voice in his head that screams for him: become a hero! He listens to the voice that says: help your mother. Help and give and save for all the things she's given.

It's a solemn evening Midoriya Izuku learns that his father is dead, and his life tilts itself over on its own head. It's a solemn evening Midoriya Izuku finds a new dream, a new goal of his.

The wounds on his skin ache painfully, but to him, it is the price of being weak. So he'll grow stronger. For his mother. For his Mama.

"It'll be okay," he whispers, more for himself. "Because I'm here."

 

 

"Ma'am, I assure you, there are no nuts in the burger."

Midoriya is tired. There's a lady with too much eyeliner who is screaming at him because there are lumps on her burger, convinced that they were trying to kill her, and he's running on four cups of Redbull and crushed Smarties. He doesn't get people.

"There are lumps!" The lady shrieks with the indignity of a woman who has seen someone murder her entire family in front of her in cold blood. "There are lumps in the burger with nuts in them, and I'm allergic!"

Midoriya, who has seen a man eat chicken nuggets with Sunny D orange juice as a dipping sauce and a soup, who has seen a man chug a whole bottle of mayonnaise like a shot in seven seconds, is barely affected by the spittle she sprays onto him as she screams about food allergies. He can handle this, he tells himself. Do it for the paycheck.

This is minimum wage, a small part of him drawls lazily. Who cares?

I do! he yells back at himself. I'm fucking broke! I'll take what I can!

"Ma'am," he tries, "Miss, I'm sorry for the inconvenience. Would you like it if I could redo it for you?"

"You're patronizing me," she says, scandalized. Izuku wonders, for the fifth time, if the paycheck was worth it. She leans forward, rudely pointing towards him. "You, boy, what's your name?"

"Midoriya Izuku," he answers, then looks at the nametag on his shirt. Is she illiterate? God, he was losing brain cells here. Working in customer service wasn't doing anything good for his head.

She nods, her attitude taking a complete 180 from seconds before. "Midoriya-san," she says gently, as if talking to a child, which, rude, who's the one who controls what she eats here? Not that he'd poison her, but it's something he's considering. "Midoriya-san, that's a nice name. I'm Akane, and I'm allergic to nuts."

Is this some kind of interview? Midoriya wonders dryly. He's tempted to answer in kind, 'And I'm allergic to bullshit, so excuse me if I throw up anytime soon,' but he would like to not get fired, so he keeps his mouth shut with the patience of a saint.

"I'm allergic to nuts," she repeats, like it's important, "and there are nuts in my burger. I didn't order nuts."

There's a line starting to form behind her, all people wearing varying levels of exhaustion and exasperation, all of which he wishes he could show but can't because he has his default customer service smile, made perfectly to show others cry for help. Someone's recording, but he can't find it in himself to care.

"I know, ma'am."

"Akane. That's my name."

"Of course, Akane-san."

"Good," she nods, seemingly satisfied. "So why are there nuts in my burger?"

He's not paid enough for this. So he does what any other underpaid teenager working at McDonald's would do in such a situation: he shoves this problem onto the manager.

"Would you like me to call the manager?" he offers, a tad too quickly. "I'm sure he is much better suited to help you."

Akane looks like she had reached the greatest epiphany in the world, which would be false, because that right had been given to Midoriya the moment he came up with the idea to pass off this problem to his manager. "Yes, show me your manager unless you want to lose a customer!"

Plan is a success, he thinks smugly, resisting the urge to pump his fist in victory. Honestly, who'd care if she didn't come again? Whatever the case, this wasn't his problem. But before he can turn around to fetch said manager, the wall next to him bursts and explodes.

There's screams that echo in the air as people scramble away from the sudden wreckage. The wall is caved in now, the debris crushing half of the counter and two cash registers, to which Midoriya mourns the loss of money. Shit, he thinks to himself, that was a good few thousand yen in there! He was going to absolutely beat the fuck out of whoever had the audacity to break into a McDonald's and destroy cash.

A masked man emerges from the dust, scales rippling under his torn shirt as he holds a gun in his hands. The mask is shoddy at best, a black ski mask that looked like it was cut with safety scissors pulled onto his head. There were too many things here for Midoriya to process. Why was this guy, a man with an obvious mutant quirk that strengthened himself enough to bring down a wall, holding a gun? Why was the man here?

"Everyone, get on the ground or I'll gut you!"

Midoriya isn't very impressed by this threat, and as everybody in the restaurant scrambles down to the dirty tile floor in a hazy panic, he stares straight into the masked man's eyes with a resignation that comes with being in customer service for far too long.

God, he's going to demand a raise after this. Better yet, maybe even file a lawsuit against this guy. Could he do that?

"Sir," he says, an all too wide and all too fake smile plastered tightly on his face. The masked robber turns to glare at him, but seeing the look on Izuku's face, gulps, the gun in his hands shaking ever so slightly. "This is a McDonald's. Why the fuck are you robbing a McDonald's."

The masked robber suddenly looks very unsure. Good for him, Midoriya thinks. He hopes the guy is sorting out his options properly right now. But, well, he has a job to do, so his smile widens almost painfully so.

"I-"

"So," he says cheerfully, "will it be dine-in or to-go?"

"I. Wait. I'm robbing this store." He says it as if he's not sure why he came here again and he's trying to remind himself why. Midoriya can understand. He can't count how many times he's walked into the kitchen or living room and wondered why he came there in the first place. He gives a nod of sage acknowledgment.

"Listen. I forget why I'm at some places before too," he tells him. "I was at a pet store once. I don't know why. I don't have any pets. I didn't even want any. I was just there."

The robber, lowering his gun, was looking progressively more confused. "What. Listen brat, get on the-"

"We're online sims," Midoriya says with a start. "Shit, why didn't I think of that. Sir, you don't need to do this. You're probably being controlled by some higher being forcing you to do this for fun. Is your life really low enough to the point where you feel the need to rob a McDonald's?"

"What the fuck are you talking about?" Then, with a crease of his brow, "You're insulting me."

"I am," Midoriya says, nodding like a teacher who's congratulating a student who got a question right after three wrong answers. Then, apologetically, "Sorry, don't have any stickers for you."

"I don't want any-"

"Sure you don't," he says sympathetically. "It's okay. I'll make sure to give you one later. I'll be extra nice and give you one with glitter."

"Shut up-"

"On a second thought," Midoriya continues on, completely ignoring the armed masked man, "your mask sucks. Looks like a primary schooler made it. Full offense. I'm revoking sticker privileges. I'll give you a high five though."

"Hey, I worked hard on this mask! I'm not taking criticism from some fucking middle-schooler."

"You should be more open-minded," he suggests helpfully. "Works wonders, really."

From the corner of his eyes, he sees most of the customers looking at him like he was going insane, to which, well, fair, but none of them has been shot and no money has been lost so-

The cash registers, he remembers with a start. The money. That this dick destroyed.


I'll drink his brain juice like a fucking McFlurry.


The robber lifts up the gun again, aiming it towards Izuku's head, but the boy has never really been the type to have any kind of self-preservation skills, and adding to the fact that this asswipe here decided to destroy the money he probably came here to steal, money that Izuku should've gotten in his pockets-

Well. This combination never bodes well.

"Okay, enough messing around," the masked scaled man snarls, fingers pressing against the trigger. "Brat, give me the money in the cashier or I will fucking shoot you."

"You wouldn't do it, bet," Midoriya replies reflexively, then realizes his mistake. Okay, that was not a good move, even for him.

The masked man looks completely baffled now, his expression of anger and confusion obvious even from beneath his mask. "Do you, like, want to die?"

"Not really," he says honestly, then headbutts the gun hard and suddenly enough to force the man to drop it. It clatters to the ground with a loud thud, and in a split second of stunned silence, Midoriya takes the chance to leap over the broken counter and grab the man by the shoulders to headbutt him.

The robber only manages to stumble back in shock to avoid it, and immediately, Midoriya throws a well-aimed jab at the back of his neck, the place he's sure there were no scales to block it, and the man falls like a sack of bricks.

Well. "That was quick," he says, almost disappointed. He nudges the unconscious man with his foot none too gently, feeling vaguely scammed, then turns back to the broken cash registers. His eyebrow twitches in irritation, then again, not bothering to be subtle, he kicks the masked man again on the side with more force.

There's dead silence in the McDonald's now, other people from outside peeking in to get a look on the situation worriedly. Midoriya wonders if any of them called the cops or heroes. The commotion should've attracted the attention of one of them at least.

He turns to the other people in the restaurant, eyes landing on the lady from before with main character syndrome. His brows furrow in thought as he tries to remember her name.

"Uh, Akabane-san," he addresses her, the woman's shoulders jolting suddenly as she scrambled to stand up. "Right. Well. Can you call the police? Heroes?"

"It's Akane," she says weakly.

"Right. That's what I said."

She blinks, opening her mouth to say something before decidedly closing her mouth shut. Not caring for whatever she was struggling with, he raises a brow as he waits for her to answer his question. She realizes this and nods sharply.

"Uh, yes, well, someone else already did. They're on their way."

Midoriya turns to the unconscious man on the floor. Maybe he should tie him up. Restrain him. Though, he's pretty sure there's nothing here that this guy couldn't rip, considering what his quirk probably was.

Five minutes later, when heroes and police have arrived, they're met with the sight of a teenage boy sitting on the back of a half-awake man with a badly cut ski mask pulled halfway off his face, the hole where his mouth was supposed to be revealing his nose instead.

When the boy notices them approaching, he waves and stands up with a bounce.

"Hello Tsukauchi-kun!" He greets the first man, smiling brightly. "Nice to see you again!"

The man in question squints, turns to look at the subdued villain on the ground, then offers a defeated look towards Izuku in return. "Midoriya-kun," he says, tired, "this is the fourth time this week I've seen you at a crime scene."

"That's. That's not too bad, right?"

"It's Wednesday."

"Well." Midoriya purses his lips in thought. "Not my fault. Why would someone even want to rob a McDonald's? I think that's just a poor life decision. Also," he pauses, tilting his head to take a full look at Tsukauchi. "Why do you look like you have a hangover?"

Tsukauchi thinks back to the bottle of vodka waiting in his desk drawer at the office, and the corner of his mouth twitches. "I don't drink on the job if that's what you're suggesting." And then, "Midoriya, I've had to handle almost ten cases of villain attacks and takedowns this month, and we're only two weeks in. All of which, you're involved in."

"Okay," he says. "And?"

"And why are you always there when a villain is?"

"Listen, you think I wanted to be attacked by a discount Sandman at Walmart?" Midoriya cries out. "That di- villain filled my grocery bag with sand and for what? He just gave me something to hit him with!" After a lapse of silence, he murmurs something about why villains were attacking shitty grocery and fast food chains in the first place.

"It's almost like you have a quirk that attracts trouble," Tsukauchi sighs. "Alright, I'll have to ask you what happened."

"Well it started when this Aka lady was yelling about how there were lumps in her hamburger..."

Tsukauchi, holding his notepad, thinks today is going to be another long day.

 

 

"Izuku, sweetie, why are you trending on Twitter?"

Midoriya turns his head slowly to where his mother was sitting, eyebrows raising up as she began to read out loud: "'Teenage boy working at McDonald's takes down a robber.' Izuku, what are you doing."

"Self defense," he offers weakly. "Also they're giving me my paycheck early."

"There's a video of you."

"Oh." Then after a thoughtful silence, "You think I'd be able to make money off of this?"

"Go to your room."

"Yes ma'am."

Midoriya, in true Midoriya fashion, somehow befriends our resident emo brainwasher, and along the way gets a cat

Yes there will be Sunny D slander ahead. That shit nasty I've said what I've said


(See the end of the chapter for more notes.)


Midoriya thinks working at a pet store is a lot better than working at a McDonald's.

Okay. Well, saying that out loud makes it obvious. It's the same pet store he ended up in for a reason only the deepest recesses of his brain knows. He won't bother trying to find it.

He manages to land a job there, somehow. The owner is a grandma who makes killer dango, but he's also seen her stab a drunkard loitering around with the end of her cane, so he makes sure never to piss her off. Maybe his looks helped with getting this job. He's heard a lot from others that he looks innocent.

He makes sure to flip them off at their face. Innocent his ass, he's faced death enough to know that he could fist fight god and win.

It's a slow shift, the occasional couple or family coming in to gawk and stare at an animal they won't get. He lounges at the counter, his fingers itching to pull out his notebook in his bag. He's been meaning to finish up the rest of his analysis on some underground heroes he managed to research after some deep digging on the internet ( the fourth page of Google ).

After the latest customer walks out the door, Midoriya slips out his notebook onto the counter and clicks on his pen. Only seconds after he begins to scribble something down, a faint scratching noise echoes behind him. He pauses, waiting for it to come again, and upon hearing silence, continues to write.

Then the noise comes again, more persistent than before, and he closes his notebook. Walking towards the back, where the scratching noise was getting louder, he slows to a stop at the back door that led to the alley between here and the convenience store next door.

This is the start of my horror movie experience, Midoriya realizes with more enthusiasm than he probably should have. With renewed vigor, he pushes open the door to find-

A cat.

It's a cute cat. But Midoriya has never really been a cat kind of guy. Feeling faintly disappointed, he stares at the calico cat who mewls up at him petulantly before walking past him and into the shop.

"Hey wait--" Midoriya instantly holds out his leg to block the cat's way into the store. "Little bastard. You can't go in there." In response, the cat gives him an annoyed paw to the leg, before attempting to move past him again. He sighs, and pushes the door shut. "There. Can't get in."

The cat shoots him an affronted look, and Midoriya stares back, equally offended, until they're locked into a staring contest he's determined not to lose. The cat has weird eyes, he thinks. He's going to win.

He doesn't know how much time passes until the cat finally blinks and turns away from him.

"Ha!" he says, triumphantly. "Loser."

Somehow, the cat seems to feel his tone of mockery, and promptly launches itself onto him, claws drawn, before he could even back away.

"Ow-! Shit, what the fu-"

Grabbing the cat by the back of its neck, he holds it up as it goes limp and stares wide-eyed into his own eyes. "Okay, sore loser," Midoriya hisses, "if you came here for food, you just lost your one last chance to get it."

The cat mewls. Midoriya sets the cat down. The cat mewls again, but louder.

"Do not," he warns. "Stop. Stop doing that."

The cat curls around his legs. He doesn't think this is normal cat behavior. Is he destined to attract the crazy ones, even with animals? "You- uh." He thinks for a second before decidedly settling on calling the cat, "Sunny D. You don't deserve a good food name. You get the imposter orange juice brand as a name. You're welcome."

Sunny D stares.

"Ungrateful," he scoffs, but gently scoops the cat up. "Fine. Fine, you're getting some cat food. We got extra in the back." Sunny D purrs in satisfaction, and Midoriya has the faint feeling he's fallen into some kind of trap. Like a pyramid scheme.

He feels like he's missing something here.

Oh. Right.

He's working right now.

Dropping Sunny D onto the floor as soon as he steps back into the pet store, he races back to the front because he does not want to be caught slacking off during his shift by the scary grandma. He'd get no dango, and there's no way he'd endanger his chance to get free food!

Luckily, as he tries to casually slide back behind the counter, there's only one other person in the store. Midoriya gives him a quick look over, the first thing catching his attention was the messy tangle of lavender hair. Huh. And he thought his hair was bad.

The teenager was browsing the cat food aisle, shuffling through it quietly as Midoriya let himself relax. Growing bored of watching the other, he turns his eyes to the back, seeing Sunny D march up to where he was and, unexpectedly, screech. Very loudly.

The purple-haired teenager flinches, and Midoriya fights down the urge to punt Sunny D onto God's doormat.

"The fuck." The teenager says. "Is that your cat?"

"No," Midoriya denies immediately, and right after Sunny D jumps onto his lap. Torn between petting them or shoving them off of him, his internal struggle is cut short as the teenager from before stares at the cat and speaks up.

"Wait, that cat is the one from the alley," he says, obviously confused. Midoriya nods slowly.

"Uh, yeah. Do you know them?"

"Her." A pause, and then, "I've been feeding her when I could. Didn't think she'd warm up so quickly to someone."

"She attacked me."

He snorts at that, his eyebrows raising in amusement. "What?"

"She attacked me," Midoriya repeats, "because she lost a staring contest with me. Sunny D is a sore loser. She is also a war criminal." Said cat has found its place on his two legs, purring softly. "Want her?"

"Nah." He puts down the cat food back onto the shelf as he murmurs questioningly under his breath 'Sunny D?' Midoriya curses at Sunny D for the loss of a potential buyer. The purple-haired teen ends the conversation there, obviously not wanting to talk any longer. Midoriya gets it, but he also thinks Sunny D is a bastard who he will absolutely not keep.

"I'm Midoriya Izuku," he says, flicking at his plastic name tag. "How about you?"

There's a small silence that follows after his question, and Midoriya almost makes a dick joke to break it before the teen answers, "Shinsou Hitoshi."

His voice is quieter than before, not in the way where he's shy, Midoriya notices, but more in the way where he doesn't want to be seen. It's the kind of quiet he understands, because Midoriya is Midoriya Izuku, the boy who defied the odds and was born powerless among the blessed. It's a quiet he understands, because it's the kind that is learned from years of being beaten down and denied of his voice.

Maybe he'll talk to this guy a little more.

"You sure you don't want Sunny D?"

"No, she was just a stray I fed."

"Ah," Midoriya says, "so you're a cat guy."

"You could say that."

"Cool." Then like a random afterthought, "I'm quirkless, by the way." Shinsou's head snaps towards him in surprise and shock. Midoriya says it without a care, as if he were describing the weather or what to eat for lunch. Shinsou, understandably, is confused.

"What."

"So what's yours?" Midoriya asks. Because Midoriya, for as much as he preaches about how he cares for nothing but money and his mom, is still a hero. That dream of his is stained onto his skin and bone, never quite fading away like he says it did.

"Why are you asking?" Shinsou's brows furrow together in slight irritation and apprehensiveness. Maybe he came on a little too strong, Midoriya thinks.

"Curious," he answers, then pulls out his notebook to wave. "I like to write about quirks. Underground heroes, daylight heroes, whatever quirk that looks interesting. Hey, don't look at me like that, I'm not a stalker. It's a hobby."

"Well if you're looking for a 'cool' quirk, you're better off asking for someone else," Shinsou says, the bitterness in his voice unhidden. Midoriya thinks he's starting to understand this boy a little better.

"Don't be like that," he drawls, fiddling with his pen. "I don't care about shit like flashiness or whatever. I just like quirks. Sue the quirkless kid for being interested in them, why don't you?"

They stare off, one of them tense and the other relaxed.

"Brainwashing," Shinsou states matter-of-factly, like he'd rather get this over with. Midoriya nods, flipping to a new page and writing something down.

"That's one I haven't seen before," he murmurs, looking back up at Shinsou. "How does it work? How do you activate it? Is it eye contact or verbal initiation? How long can you hold it? How many people can you control at once?"

"...That's a lot of questions."

"Sorry," Midoriya says, not apologetic. "So?"

"You- that's it?" Shinsou frowns, but it's less angry and more confused. "That's all you're going to ask? Say?"

"Yeah?" Midoriya tilts his head slightly in thought. "What else? Well, from what I'm seeing, I guess people don't really like your quirk, huh." Shinsou barely winces, but it's enough for Midoriya to catch on. "What do you want me to say, that your quirk is perfect for being a villain?"

Before Shinsou could answer, Midoriya continued to talk. "Listen, I don't really give a shit. Quirks depend on the user, yeah? Thought that was pretty common knowledge. You wanna be a hero?" Shinsou could only mutely nod, and Midoriya grins with all teeth, "There you go! Ignore the dipshits who say that stuff. Maybe even beat them up. That's what I did."

"Beat them up," Shinsou reiterates slowly. "I'm not a delinquent."

"Me neither," Midoriya shrugs. "Do I look like one?"

"I feel like Sunny D isn't the only one here who's committed war crimes."

"That's. Okay, that's fair. But still," Midoriya taps his pen on the counter. "You haven't answered my question."

"I don't need to."

"Stop making fair points."

"What is wrong with you," Shinsou says, not really a question but put off nonetheless. There's no malice in his voice, so Midoriya doesn't take much offense. Again, Shinsou makes another valid point.

"Take your pick," Midoriya says, spreading his arms like he's trying to sell something. He grins. "The trauma? The whole quirkless thing? The fact I've run into ten villains this month?"

"You've what." And then, "Do you always overshare with strangers?"

"Maybe," Midoriya admits, unashamedly. "Not as much as this usually. Be the cryptid you want to see in your life, y'know."

"I. I really don't." Shinsou looks like he aged five years from this conversation. "Will you leave me alone if I tell you how my quirk works?" Midoriya shrugs, but the shit-eating grin on his face only gives him a bad feeling.

"Possibly. I don't give guarantees."

And then suddenly everything goes foggy. Midoriya feels himself go absolutely still, and almost as if he weren't in his own body. Something tugs at his mind, binding it, and as he tries to move anything - his hands, his legs, his head - he is only met with failure.

Brainwashing, his mind supplies. This is so fucking cool.

Then with a start, he's back in the pet store by the counter, in front of Shinsou. The boy looks tired, moreso, but Izuku smiles widely in fascination.

"So it's verbal? Do I have to answer a question, or just reply back to whatever you say? I couldn't control myself at all! That quirk has way too many applications-"

"Whoa, whoa, whoa, wait." Shinsou massages his temple, a disbelieving chuckle escaping his lips. "You just got brainwashed."

"Yeah?"

"You just got brainwashed."

"I heard you the first time."

"Do you have any sense of self preservation or danger?" Shinsou asks, aghast.

"That is a good question." He pauses. "I've heard that I don't." Midoriya carelessly waves his hand, as if brushing off the topic. "Anyways, mind telling me the details of your quirk? Man, it felt like I was having sleep paralysis but without the demon."

"It's a question you have to answer for it to activate," Shinsou says, giving up on trying to understand the boy in front of him. He came here for cat food and instead gets a guy his age he's pretty sure must've committed some form of tax fraud. "I can't make the person do any complicated things, like answering questions."

"Probably need to train with it more to do that," Midoriya mutters, his pen flying across his notebook as he quickly writes down the information. "Verbal activation, answering a question, can't make the controlled do anything complicated..."

Shinsou stares at him as he continues to mutter rapidfire under his breath, soon filling up two pages in what seemed like no time.

"Shinsou," Midoriya says suddenly, "can I have your number?"

"What," Shinsou says, caught off guard. "What."

"You probably stop by here a lot," Midoriya says, his
